text.description: Mondadori, the magazine publisher controlled by Silvio Berlusconi, is reported to have expressed interest in Emap's £700m consumer magazine division. By Mark Sweney.
text.title: Berlusconi's Mondadori linked to Emap buy-up

main.p: Mondadori, the Italian magazine publisher controlled by Silvio Berlusconi, has expressed interest in buying Emap's £700m consumer magazine division, according to a report today.

The Italian publisher and Lagardere-owned Hachette Filipacchi, whose British operations are run by former Emap chief executive Kevin Hand, have asked for a sales memorandum from UK radio and magazine business, according to today's Times.
Mondadori bought up Emap's struggling French publishing business for £380m in June last year.
Both companies had previously been touted by analysts as prime candidates for Emap's consumer magazine division, which includes titles such as Heat, Closer, Grazia and FHM.
Emap is conducting a strategic review of its operation with suitors circling its three divisions - business-to-business publishing, consumer magazines and radio.
Reed Elsevier, United Business Media, and Informa have are reported to have requested information on the £1.3bn business-to-business operation, as had been speculated by analysts.
UBM owns a division called CMP, whose management includes former Emap finance director Gary Hughes.
Venture capitalist group Chaterhouse has also reportedly asked for information on Emap's business unit.
GCap Media and Charles Allen's Global Radio have been named as firms that could be interested in Emap's radio operation.
However, analysts describe the radio division - valued conservatively as worth around £360m - as difficult due to a "hostile" regulatory environment for trade buyers such as GCap.
GCap, with the likes of Capital Radio and Xfm, and Global Radio with Heart FM, have geographical overlaps with Emap's radio station networks, which include Kiss and Magic.
